ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained the ability to think critically about Immunology. This was an amazing course with such an intentional, positive structure/modules that facilitated student learning!
Great review of immunobiology and quite comprehensive
General immunology knowledge
I learned a lot about the immune system and its functions.
improved the understanding of immunology and applications
The course provided insight into current advances and new discoveries in immunology, as well as some overview onto fundamental immunological principles.

The different PIs provided a broad, but at the same time deep overview of the immune system. This help with following immunological presentations (Research in progress, etc.) and understanding immunological concepts.
I gained/enhanced my foundational immunology knowledge.

With this course, I was able to go from having foundational, specialized knowledge about immunology to having a broad, comprehensive knowledge. This knowledge allowed me to think critically about the papers that I was reading and the data I generated from my rotations. I was able to connect data and topics from RIP and seminar series lectures with further concepts in immunology and felt confident in understanding from this course to think creatively and ponder gaps or open questions in the field.
Basic immunology
Immunological knowledge
Overview and helpful details of the immune system

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths in this class included the curriculum's structure, which allowed you to integrate knowledge within a section more fully and apply it to future content. I enjoyed the discussion sections each week that reviewed key content as well.

I do not see any weaknesses in this course. If you are interested in immunology, please take this! It's amazing to have so many different faculty presenting on what they study and pioneer knowledge in - as well as to get a taste of the work being done in the Department of Immunobiology.

I think it's a great summary of Immunology and it's really nice that each lecture or so is a different professor to provide students with some change. While this is net good, I do think this can be hard for the TFs at times because there wasn't any "standardized" components for any of the lectures - this made it challenging to study and I'm sure was frustrating for the teaching staff who often times had to adjust or cut lectures from exams/homework due to the confusion.
There could be more cohesiveness between the lecturers and more exam time. The TA sessions were great.

I loved the discussion sections, I found them to be very helpful. I think the class was a little too high level at times, but I have also never taken immunology before and was expecting more of an introductory course.
none

Strengths: Good concept of trying to fit in material necessary for a PhD student to succeed immunology.

Weaknesses: Lectures not always clear in preparing for exams, TA sessions highly variable by teacher, and exams are not always representative of focused topics during course. Not well suited for undergraduates to take.

The course felt incredibly disjointed. Lecturers would often cover the same information multiple times and what we learned in lecture was often not covered on the exam. I regularly attended lectures, but it would often feel like a waste of my time due to covering the same material multiple times and knowing that much of the information from the lectures would not be seen on an exam.
Something that can be improved is having the lecture slides uploaded promptly. Some of the slides for a few classes were never uploaded.

Strengths: Each PI adeptly presents a topic within their expertise, enabling them to simplify complex information into basic concepts while incorporating essential details.

Weaknesses: For this academic year, it was my impression that the TAs held more influence over the exams than the PIs, although this might be a subjective observation. Despite PIs stating that knowledge of XYZ was unnecessary, the TAs overloaded evening sessions with precisely those XYZ details. Furthermore, although the last exam was declared non-cumulative, some questions were distinctly focused on details from the initial module, which were not revisited in the third module. More transparency about this discrepancy would have been appreciated, and additional time to review modules 1 and 2 for the last exam (held just two days after the final lecture) would have been beneficial. Perhaps scheduling the third exam after the reading period could have provided more preparation time.
I liked the way the modules were set up to teach the material. I really enjoyed the final module that focused more on conceptual learning.

A huge strength of this course was that it was able to cover so much information but be able to connect the topics and lectures to a wider concept and to each other. Having PIs with expertise in the field give lectures was fantastic as well. I feel this course could be improved by having the PIs giving the lecture have a bit more guidance on what needs to be covered. There were a few occasions where the lecturer didn't cover the material that would be on the exam and the TA session would have to cover it instead. This was fine but I feel it would be much more efficient and interesting if the topic had been covered in the lecture and the TA session could just be a review. Also, the amount of material covered in the exams felt very inconsistent. For instance, the first exam was pretty light but then the second one covered all of B and T cell development, signaling, effector functions, activation, etc. I feel that this could be improved by having maybe an extra exam added (break up the second exam material into two exams) or add material from the second exam into the first or third exam.

Strength: all the faculty members are very professional and nice.
Weakness: The exams are too close to the last lecture of each module.

Course organization could be improved because some lectures focused on the textbook chapters listed, whereas some didnt and instead used research and review papers. Content was good, but it was a lot of information, and it could make it hard to know what to focus on studying. 

Exam grading could also be modified. According to the TAs, they were grading the short answer and essay questions strictly based on what was written on the answer keys. But what could happen was students could get points off for writing the right things because their answers were not specific enough. Points could also be taken off for not writing something mentioned in the answer key. And it could be difficult to know how much details to put down or exactly how they wanted the question to be answered for certain types of questions

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to another student, granted they were interested in Immunology. The concepts are inherently difficult, but it is very much worth it for a student who is interested in Immunobiology to take this class. It is taught very well.
Yes, I think it's a really great way to get an overview of the field of Immunology
Yes, I did learn a ton about immunology.

Yes! If you want to learn the fundamentals of immunology, this was a fantastic course. You also get to learn from the leading experts in the field, which is a remarkably unique opportunity. One of the most interesting and well organized courses I've taken so far.
yes. fundamental class for immunology.
I would only recommend this to graduate students, it does not feel appropriate for undergraduates.

No. The lectures were too disjointed and the exams included information that non-immunology students do not regularly cover. The third and final exams had questions that required an understanding of immunology that went beyond the expectation of the course and were more suited for only the Immunology PhD students.
I would recommend this course for students deeply interested in immunology and if it is more ore less a requirement. Otherwise, I would just audit instead of taking the three exams.
I would recommend this course to anyone that wants to gain foundational knowledge in immunology.
I would. It did a great job of covering a ton of information and providing a really solid foundation of knowledge for the PhD. Really interesting too.
Yes, because it's very useful for learning immunology.

extras.title: IBIO 530 01/MBIO 530 01/MCDB 430 01/MCDB 530 01 - Biology of the Immune System
